facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2206 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2206 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 23. 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 888 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated February 23, 1966 of Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 888 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 23. 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 888 of 1961. V. Gupte Naunit Lal S.S. Khanduja and Swaranjit Sodhi for the appellants.

facts.text: Respondent Hubli Dharwar Municipal Corporation was originally constituted as a Borough under Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the Hubli Dharwar Municipal Corporation, was originally companystituted as a Borough under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925  hereinafter referred to as the Act . At the relevant time, when the disputes leading to the suit arose, it was still a Borough, but it became a Corporation subsequently in the year 1962.

facts.text: Borough became Corporation in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: it was still a Borough, but it became a Corporation subsequently in the year 1962. The Borough owned several buildings in Dharwar. Some of these buildings were given on leases, to the appellants.

facts.text: Borough owned several buildings in Dharwar and leased some to appellants in March and April 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Borough owned several buildings in Dharwar. Some of these buildings were given on leases, to the appellants. These leases were executed in favour of the appellants by the Borough some time in March and April, 1953.

facts.text: General Committee Resolution No. 36 dated 29th June 1953 decided to recover house-tax from tenants of municipal buildings.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, by a General Committee Resolution No. 36 dated 29th June, 1953, the Borough decided to recover house-tax and other municipal taxes from the private individuals who were tenants of the municipal buildings leased out to them.

facts.text: Notice issued by President of Borough requiring citizens in occupation of municipal buildings to pay taxes.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this Resolution, a numberice was issued by the President of the Borough that all the citizens in occupation of the buildings owned by the Municipality must pay the taxes assessed on them in respect of the premises under their occupation.

facts.text: Appellants preferred joint objections against levy of house-tax on 9th September 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th September, 1953, the appellants preferred joint objections against the levy of the house-tax and its realisation from them.

facts.text: Government of Bombay sanctioned amendment to House-tax Rules on 9th September 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th September, 1954, the Government of Bombay sanctioned the amendment to the then existing Housetax-Rules framed under the Act in respect of this Borough,

facts.text: General Committee passed Resolution on 19th February 1955 sanctioning levy of taxes on municipal buildings from 1st April 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and the General Committee passed a Resolution on the 19th February, 1955 sanctioning the levy of taxes on Municipal owned buildings, adopting the sanctioned taxes,.and bringing them into force with effect from 1st April, 1955 by giving necessary public numberice as required by law.

facts.text: Taxes came into force on 1st April 1955 after notice under section 77 published on 25th February 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Notice under section 77 was published on 25th February, 1955 and then the taxes came into forct on 1st April, 1955.

facts.text: Fresh lease-deeds executed by respondent in favour of appellants on 11th May 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, fresh lease-deeds were executed by the respondent in favour of the appellants on 11th May, 1955.

facts.text: No mention of tenants' liability to pay house-tax in original 1953 leases or fresh 1955 leases.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that, neither in the original leases of 1953, number in the fresh leases of 1955, was there any mention about liability of the tenants to pay the house- tax.

facts.text: Bills issued by respondent to appellants for house-tax on leased buildings.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the execution of these fresh leases, bills were received from the respondent by the appellants calling upon them to pay the house-tax imposed in respect of the. buildings belonging the respondent which were on lease with the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants filed suit challenging legality of house-tax imposition on municipality's own buildings.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereafter filed the suit out of which the present appeal has arisen, challenging the legality of the imposition of the tax. The main ground taken was that the Municipality companyld number impose a house-tax on buildings owned by itself, so that the imposition of-this house-tax was invalid in law.

facts.text: Respondent resisted suit claiming tax was valid and suit bad for lack of notice under section 206-A.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted on the plea that it was a valid taxation. A further defence was taken that the suit was bad for failure, on the part of the appellants to give numberice to the respondent under section 206-A of the Act.

facts.text: Trial Court decreed suit holding municipality not competent to levy excess over rent and no notice under s.206-A needed.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court decreed the suit, holding that the respondent was, number legally companypetent to levy from the tenants, any sum in excess of the agreed rents, and the bills issued for recovery of excess were number valid and that, in the circumstances of this case. numberice under s. 206-A of the Act was number necessary.

facts.text: First Appellate Court (Additional District Judge) dismissed suit for want of notice under s.206-A.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal,.the and Additional District Judge agreed with the trial Court that- the levy of the tax was number justified, but held that the suit, without a proper numberice under section 206-A of the Act was number maintainable He therefore, allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit with companyts.

facts.text: Mysore High Court upheld dismissal of suit on grounds that tax valid and no notice under s.206-A.

anchor.surface_text: On second appeal, the High Court of Mysore upheld the dismissal of the suit, but on both the grounds, viz., that the tax was validly levied, and that the suit was number maintainable for want of proper numberice under section 206-A of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that municipality can impose house-tax on its own buildings, primarily payable by occupier/tenant.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree, with learned companynsel for the appellants that this scheme of the Act companytains any indication that buildings belonging to the municipality itself cannot be subjected to the house-tax which can be imposed under section 73 of the Act. In fact, the language of section 85 specifically envisages imposition of such a tax on buildings belonging to the municipality.

facts.text: Appellants sued in representative capacity for all tenants of Borough buildings.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the appellants sued the Borough in a representative capacity as representing all the tenants of buildings belonging to the Borough.

facts.text: Supreme Court found tax validly imposed, suit fails; notice issue immaterial.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we fully agree with the High Court that the tax was validly imposed and the suit challenging its realisation from the appellants had to fail. In view of our decision on the validity of the tax, the question whether a numberice under section 206-A of the Act was necessary or number becomes immaterial.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 23. 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 888 of 1961.

The power to impose a tax on buildings is contained in section 73 of the Act, the relevant portion of which is as follows 73.  1  Subject to any general or special orders which the State Government may make in this behalf and to the provisions of sections 75 and 76 a municipality may impose for the purposes of this Act any of the following taxes, namely -  1  a rate on building or lands. or both situate with-

concepts.interpretation: No indication in the scheme that municipality cannot impose house-tax on its own buildings; power to impose rate on buildings or lands.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: to the house-tax which can be imposed under section 73 of the Act. In fact, the language of section 85 specifically envisages imposition of such a tax

concepts.unlisted_description: Power of municipality to impose taxes including rate on buildings or lands

anchor.surface_text: Finally, attention was drawn to the provisions of section 85, which lays down who is to be primarily responsible for payment of the tax, in the following language- A tax imposed in the form of a rate on buildings or land or both. shall be leviable primarily from the actual occupier of the property upon which the tax is assessed if he is the owner of the property, or holds it on a building, or other lease from the Government or from the municipality,

concepts.interpretation: Specifically envisages imposition of tax on buildings belonging to the municipality; primarily leviable from occupier holding on lease from municipality.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: 85 specifically envisages imposition of such a tax on buildings belonging to the municipality. It clearly lays down that such a tax shall be leviable

concepts.unlisted_description: Primary liability for payment of tax on buildings or land

anchor.surface_text: Section 75 then lays down the procedure for imposition of the tax and s. 75 c  gives the right of filing objections to the inhabitants of the borough.

concepts.interpretation: Procedure for imposition of tax; right of objections to inhabitants, not limited to owners.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: companypleted assessment list is to be published and gives a right to every person claiming to be either the owner or occupier of property included i

anchor.surface_text: Section 74 then provides for payment of an ad hoc sum ascertained in the manner provided in that section by the Government or district local board in lieu of a rate on buildings vesting in the Government or in the district local boards which are exempted under clause  a  of the proviso quoted above.

concepts.unlisted_description: Payment in lieu of taxes by government or local boards for exempted buildings

anchor.surface_text: Section 78 makes provision for preparation of an assessment list and requires that that list should contain the names of the owner as well as occupier, if known.

concepts.unlisted_description: Preparation of assessment list including owner and occupier

anchor.surface_text: Section 79 deals with cases where the person primarily liable for payment of this tax cannot be ascertained, and makes it sufficient to designate him in the assessment book as the holder of such premises without further description.

concepts.unlisted_description: Designation of liable person in assessment when not ascertained

anchor.surface_text: Section 80 lays down the manner in which the completed assessment list is to be published and gives a right to every person claiming to be either the owner or occupier of property included in the list, and any agent of such person, to inspect the list and to make extracts therefrom without charge.

concepts.unlisted_description: Publication of assessment list and right to inspect

arguments.claim: Municipality can impose house-tax on own buildings under s.73; primarily payable by occupier/tenant per s.85

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree, with learned counsel for the appellants that this scheme of the Act contains any indication that buildings belonging to the municipality itself cannot be subjected to the house-tax which can be imposed under section 73 of the Act. In fact, the language of section 85 specifically envisages imposition of such a tax on buildings belonging to the municipality.

arguments.claim: Tax validly imposed; suit fails; notice under s.206-A immaterial

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we fully agree with the High Court that the tax was validly imposed and the suit challenging its realisation from the appellants had to fail. In view of our decision on the validity of the tax, the question whether a notice under section 206-A of the Act was necessary or not becomes immaterial.

holdings.text: The scheme of the Act contains no indication that buildings belonging to the municipality itself cannot be subjected to the house-tax which can be imposed under section 73 of the Act. In fact, the language of section 85 specifically envisages imposition of such a tax on buildings belonging to the municipality.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree, with learned counsel for the appellants that this scheme of the Act contains any indication that buildings belonging to the municipality itself cannot be subjected to the house-tax which can be imposed under section 73 of the Act. In fact, the language of section 85 specifically envisages imposition of such a tax on buildings belonging to the municipality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of statutory scheme (ss.73-80,85) reveals no exemption for municipal buildings; s.85 expressly provides for primary liability on occupier/lessee of municipal property, presupposing tax applicability.

holdings.text: A tax imposed under section 73 on municipal buildings is leviable primarily from the actual occupier who holds it on lease from the municipality.

anchor.surface_text: It clearly lays down that such a tax shall be leviable primarily from the actual occupier of the property on which the tax is assessed, even if he holds it on a lease from the municipality. The fixation of such responsibility primarily on the occupier holding a building on lease from the municipality could only be laid down on the basis that the buildings owned by the municipality can be subjected to the tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.85 imposes primary responsibility on lessee of municipal buildings, confirming tax imposition valid.

holdings.text: The tax was validly imposed and the suit challenging its realisation from the appellants had to fail.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we fully agree with the High Court that the tax was validly imposed and the suit challenging its realisation from the appellants had to fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of ss.73 and 85 to facts of imposition and levy on appellants as tenants confirms validity; suit dismissed accordingly.

holdings.text: In view of our decision on the validity of the tax, the question whether a notice under section 206-A of the Act was necessary or not becomes immaterial.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our decision on the validity of the tax, the question whether a notice under section 206-A of the Act was necessary or not becomes immaterial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Once substantive validity upheld, procedural notice requirement need not be decided.
